abstract_summ: Our results showed that Black patients with COVID-19 have a significantly higher risk of mortality, hospitalization, and invasive mechanical ventilation compared to White patients.Importance COVID-19 epidemiological data show higher mortality rates among males compared to females.Conclusion In conclusion, males are more severely affected and have higher mortality from COVID-19.Black patients had higher prevalences of obesity, diabetes, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease than white patients.Importance: Racial disparities in COVID-19 outcomes have been amplified during this pandemic and reports on outcomes in African-American (AA) populations, known to have higher rates of cardiovascular (CV) comorbidities, remain limited.
title_summ: Medical Vulnerability of Young Adults to Severe COVID-19 Illness—Data From the National Health Interview SurveyRace/Ethnicity, Underlying Medical Conditions, Homelessness, and Hospitalization Status of Adult Patients with COVID-19 at an Urban Safety-Net Medical Center - Boston, Massachusetts, 2020.Sex-specific differences in COVID-19 testing, cases and outcomes: a population-wide study in Ontario, CanadaOutcomes and Cardiovascular Comorbidities in a Predominantly African-American Population with COVID-19COVID-19 outcomes, risk factors and associations by race: a comprehensive analysis using electronic health records data in Michigan MedicineClinical, Behavioral and Social Factors Associated with Racial Disparities in Hospitalized and Ambulatory COVID-19 Patients from an Integrated Health Care System in GeorgiaGender-Based Disparities in COVID-19: Clinical Characteristics and Propensity-matched Analysis of OutcomesA phenome-wide association study (PheWAS) of COVID-19 outcomes by race using the electronic health records data in Michigan MedicineComorbidities and Disparities in Outcomes of COVID-19 Among African American and White PatientsHospitalization and Mortality among Black Patients and White Patients with Covid-19
title_abstract_phrases: Our results showed that Black patients with COVID-19 have a significantly higher risk of mortality, hospitalization, and invasive mechanical ventilation compared to White patients.Gender-Based Disparities in COVID-19: Clinical Characteristics and Propensity-matched Analysis of OutcomesImportance COVID-19 epidemiological data show higher mortality rates among males compared to females.Outcomes and Cardiovascular Comorbidities in a Predominantly African-American Population with COVID-19Importance: Racial disparities in COVID-19 outcomes have been amplified during this pandemic and reports on outcomes in African-American (AA) populations, known to have higher rates of cardiovascular (CV) comorbidities, remain limited.Black patients had higher prevalences of obesity, diabetes, hypertension, and chronic kidney disease than white patients.Comorbidities and Disparities in Outcomes of COVID-19 Among African American and White PatientsInitial surveillance data suggests a disproportionately high number of deaths among Black patients with COVID-19.
